author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russia Sentences Alsu Kurmasheva, American Editor, to a Penal Colony
description: Ms. Kurmasheva, a Russian American working for Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, had been charged in relation to an antiwar book she edited.
content: A court in Russia said on Monday that it had convicted a Russian American editor for Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, an American broadcaster funded by the United States government, to six and a half years in a penal colony for spreading false information about the Russian Army.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Wade
title: When Women Wits Ruled London’s Swankiest Salons
description: A new book by Susannah Gibson spotlights the 18th-century Bluestockings, who aspired to have their writings and ideas accorded the same respect as men’s.
content: In 1790, Mary Wollstonecraft sat down to write a fan letter. “You are the only female writer who I coincide in opinion with respecting the rank our sex ought to attain in the world,” she wrote in excitement to Catharine Macaulay. Macaulay had recently published her treatise “Letters on Education,” arguing that boys and girls should be taught the same curriculum, since “true wisdom … is as useful to women as men” — a principle that formed the bedrock, two years later, of Wollstonecraft’s triumphant “A Vindication of the Rights of Woman.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters and Clyde McGrady
title: Some Black Voters Say They Wonder if a Black Woman Can Win
description: In interviews, some Black voters expressed concern about whether Americans were ready to elect Kamala Harris, who has the backing of President Biden.
content: President Biden’s endorsement of Vice President Kamala Harris to replace him on the Democratic ticket left some Black voters anxiously wondering whether Americans were ready to elect a Black woman to the nation’s highest office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Al Sharpton
title: Al Sharpton: How Democrats Can Get the Campaign Back on Track
description: History will remember what this former lion of the Senate accomplished from the West Wing to improve Black communities across the nation.
content: Joe Biden is more than this moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Adam Rasgon
title: China is hosting talks between the two main Palestinian factions, but expectations are low.
description: Top officials from Hamas and Fatah, the two rival Palestinian factions, are meeting in Beijing this week as China seeks to show it is playing a bigger role in diplomacy in the Middle East.
content: Top officials from Hamas and Fatah, the two rival Palestinian factions, are meeting in Beijing this week as China seeks to show it is playing a bigger role in diplomacy in the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: The Olympics and ‘Surreal Life: Villa of Secrets’
description: The opening ceremony airs on NBC. MTV reboots a reality show.
content: For those who still enjoy a cable subscription, here is a selection of cable and network TV shows, movies and specials that broadcast this week, July 22-28. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erica L. Green and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Harris Steps Into the Spotlight, Reintroducing Herself on Her Own Terms
description: Vice President Kamala Harris scooped up endorsements and wasted no time starting to build her new profile as the presumptive nominee and the new hope for defeating former President Donald J. Trump.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris drew on her past as a prosecutor on Monday in her first campaign appearance since President Biden dropped his re-election bid, saying her law enforcement background would help her defeat a rival who is a convicted criminal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: Can Robert Menendez’s Bribery Conviction Survive an Appeal?
description: The Supreme Court has narrowed the legal definition of corruption, with political figures in New York and elsewhere having their convictions overturned as a result.
content: After Senator Robert Menendez was found guilty of bribery and corruption charges, his lawyers said they would appeal his conviction aggressively and expected that he would be vindicated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3.3 Million Homes in California
description: A 1927 Spanish-style house with a guest cottage in Los Angeles, an Arts and Crafts bungalow in Sonoma and a four-bedroom home with a guesthouse in Torrance.
content: This house is in Carthay Circle, an early example of a planned community in Los Angeles and one of the first parts of the city to have underground power lines. It was designed by Horatio W. Bishop, an architect who worked extensively in the neighborhood during the 1920s and 1930s, and retains much of its original charm; the sellers have restored the hardwood floors, the millwork and the colorful tile in one of the bathrooms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat, David French, Michelle Goldberg and Lydia Polgreen
title: Is It a Mistake for Democrats to Go All In on Harris? Four Columnists on the Party’s Moves.
description: As Democratic leaders fall in line behind Harris, her strengths and weaknesses warrant a closer look.
content: Patrick Healy, the deputy Opinion editor, hosted an online conversation with the Times Opinion columnists Ross Douthat, David French, Michelle Goldberg and Lydia Polgreen to discuss where Democrats go from here — whether the party should coalesce unreservedly around Kamala Harris as its presidential nominee, what her strengths and weaknesses are, how she should run against Donald Trump, what it will take to beat him and who the Democratic V.P. nominee should be this year. This conversation has been edited for length and clarity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Biden’s Withdrawal From Race, a Reporter’s Call to Action
description: Reid J. Epstein, a politics reporter at The New York Times, had just finished eating cupcakes at his son’s birthday party when he saw Biden’s bombshell announcement. He raced home, and got to work.
content: At 1:46 E.S.T. on Sunday afternoon, President Biden announced on social media that he would end his re-election campaign, following weeks of mounting pressure from voters and politicians across the aisle. Soon after, Mr. Biden endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Trial in Bombing of U.S. Warship Set to Start 25 Years After Attack
description: The judge reserved a courtroom for fall 2025. Seventeen U.S. sailors were killed in the bombing, which was a precursor to the 9/11 terrorist attacks.
content: The death-penalty trial of a prisoner accused of plotting the bombing of the U.S.S. Cole warship has been set to begin in October 2025. If the plan holds, the trial would coincide with the 25th anniversary of the Qaeda attack, which killed 17 U.S. sailors off the coast of Yemen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: The Promise, and Risks, in Turning to Kamala Harris
description: In a sprint of a race, Ms. Harris is poised to attack Donald Trump on his felonies and, in a 2024 twist, his age, but Republicans will be galvanized to fight her, too.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris swiftly established herself as the Democratic front-runner to take on Donald J. Trump within hours of President Biden’s exit on Sunday, fundamentally rewiring the presidential contest at warp speed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Democrats Cleared the Path for Harris’s Nomination
description: Also, lawmakers called for the Secret Service director to resign. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris has already secured the endorsement of the vast majority of elected Democrats, just a day after President Biden made the stunning announcement that he was dropping his re-election bid. Few obvious challengers to her nomination remain, as the party anxiously looks to move past the divisions that have torn it apart for weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyce McFadden
title: They Drive for a Living and Say New York Traffic Is ‘the Worst Ever’
description: There are more than 90,000 taxis, Ubers and Lyfts in New York City, making it hard for those drivers — and everyone else — to maneuver through the streets.
content: This is Street Wars, a weekly series on the battle for space on New York’s streets and sidewalks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Why Obama Hasn’t Endorsed Harris
description: The former president has positioned himself as an impartial elder statesman above intraparty machinations and was neutral during the 2020 Democratic primaries.
content: Many of the marquee names in Democratic politics began quickly lining up behind Vice President Kamala Harris on Sunday, but one towering presence in the party held back: Barack Obama.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Iyad Abuheweila
title: Israel Orders New Evacuation in Gaza as Aid Workers Say Bombing Kills Dozens
description: Israeli forces said they struck dozens of sites in Khan Younis where Hamas operated and fired rockets, and they shrank the “humanitarian zone” where civilians had been told to go.
content: The Israeli military ordered residents to evacuate part of Khan Younis in the southern Gaza Strip on Monday and bombarded the area, killing scores of people and wounding hundreds, local health officials reported, adding to the misery of a city already deeply scarred by nine and a half months of war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: How to Feed 15,000 Olympians in Paris? Start With Baguettes.
description: The French will have to meet a welter of health and cultural requirements, but they still want to serve up some delight.
content: The unforgettable moment when a competing athlete first enters the Olympic Village in Paris may be defined not by the complex’s impressive size and sweep, but by a smell: the scent of freshly baked baguettes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Ethics Committee Moves Swiftly to Tee Up Possible Expulsion of Menendez
description: Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey was found guilty of bribery and corruption last week.
content: The bipartisan Senate Ethics Committee voted unanimously on Monday to advance an inquiry into Senator Robert Menendez of New Jersey, signaling that it was moving swiftly to lay the groundwork to potentially expel him after his federal bribery conviction last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Reid J. Epstein
title: Harris Clinches Majority of Delegates as She Closes In on Nomination
description: On her first full day in the race, Kamala Harris drew endorsements from her final possible rivals, hauled in record sums of cash and attacked Donald Trump.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris moved swiftly to assert herself as the de facto Democratic nominee for president on Monday, her first full day as a candidate, as virtually every potential remaining rival bowed out and she clinched the support of enough delegates to win the nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Karaian and River Akira Davis
title: Investors React to Election Upheaval, Reassessing Their Political Bets
description: A new Democratic ticket could alter investors’ perceived election odds, with implications for stocks, bonds, the dollar and more.
content: Investors around the world are trying to gauge how President Biden’s decision to drop out of the presidential race will affect stocks, bonds, the dollar and other markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Kamala Harris and the Political Power of Joy
description: Suddenly, a campaign that felt like a bleak death march has become fun.
content: After months of alternating between despair and terror, a lot of Democrats are feeling positively unburdened. In the day since President Biden stepped aside and the party coalesced behind Vice President Kamala Harris, a euphoric giddiness has fallen over the party.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: Kamala Harris’s Presidential Bid Is Getting a Pop Music Rollout Online
description: Charli XCX, John Legend and other musicians posted messages supporting the vice president’s nomination, while fans remixed an old speech into pop hits on TikTok.
content: Within hours of President Biden’s announcement that he would not seek re-election and would instead endorse Vice President Kamala Harris, social media exploded with support from the pop music world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Vanessa Friedman
title: With Biden’s Endorsement of Harris, What’s Next?
description: Many Democrats endorsed the vice president as their party’s standard-bearer, but some donors questioned whether more competition for the role was needed.
content: The shock waves from President Biden ending his re-election bid, after weeks of pressure to step aside, are still reverberating around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: What Should I Wear to the Olympics?
description: A reader visiting Paris for the Summer Games wonders about the fashion guidelines for spectators. Our fashion critic offers advice on how to dress practically and respectfully.
content: The interesting thing about the Olympics, unlike almost any other sporting event (except, maybe, the World Cup), is that attendees in the stands, like the athletes themselves, represent their country — even if unofficially. At least that’s how they are seen by locals. Which means that if you are going to the Olympics, which are generally a little more formal than other big sporting events because of the history, ceremony and mythology involved, a little more dressing up is required.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 408, July 23, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Tuesday Briefing: Support Builds for Kamala Harris
description: Plus, the head of the Secret Service testified before Congress about the assassination attempt on Donald Trump.
content: Many prominent figures in the Democratic Party said yesterday that they backed Vice President Kamala Harris as their new nominee to be president, just a day after President Biden announced that he was ending his campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: What to Know About Kamala Harris’s Husband, Doug Emhoff
description: As the spouse of the first woman to be vice president, Doug Emhoff has focused on combating antisemitism and expanding access to legal aid.
content: Doug Emhoff, the second gentleman, would become the country’s first-ever first gentleman if Vice President Kamala Harris were to win the presidency in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: A Cheapskate in Chicago
description: Recommendations from a city-dweller on where to find excellence in music, art, theater and food without spending a fortune.
content: One June morning, I went to see what the tourists were up to in Chicago, where I live. My mission was to join them while adhering to a strict travel budget. So I started with a free Chicago Greeter tour of the downtown Loop, ground zero for visitors and home to popular attractions like Millennium Park and the Art Institute of Chicago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Biden Is Out of the Race. Trump Is Still Attacking Him.
description: In his posts since Mr. Biden’s announcement, Mr. Trump has so far not taken direct aim at Kamala Harris, who is seeking the Democratic nomination.
content: Shortly after President Biden announced he was ending his re-election campaign, former President Donald J. Trump on Sunday afternoon posted on social media a forceful attack denouncing him. Over the next hours, he posted several more.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: 10 French Wines to Drink While Watching the Olympics
description: These easygoing bottles — red, white, rosé and sparkling — are perfect for relaxing and just right for watching the Paris games from afar.
content: The Summer Olympics begins in late July, and, I have to say, I’m with all the Parisians renting out their apartments and fleeing their city. If the games were in New York, I might do the same.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘House of the Dragon’ Season 2, Episode 6 Recap: The Black Queen’s Gambit
description: Rhaenyra sends a gift to the common people of King’s Landing. There may be some strings attached.
content: The hug lasts 45 seconds before they kiss. Yes, I counted. In the terms of that episode of “Curb Your Enthusiasm” where Larry hugs Auntie Rae for a little too long, it’s nine “five Mississippi”s. And like any long, drawn-out take on this densely packed show, it stops everything in its tracks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Emad Mekay
title: Heat Waves Are Pounding Egypt, and Often There’s No A.C.
description: Daily power cuts have been plaguing Egypt during an extraordinarily hot summer. Now the blackouts may be temporarily suspended, but the damage to confidence in the government has already been done.
content: Egyptian summers have always been hot. But it has not always been this hot, with temperatures barely dipping below 100 degrees in Cairo since May, testing tempers and massacring houseplants. And it has never been this hot at a time when the government has imposed power cuts on most of the country for more than a year, plunging millions into sweaty, un-air-conditioned misery for hours each day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Meacham
title: Joe Biden, My Friend and an American Hero
description: He never surrendered the hope that a frail and fallible world could be made stronger if people could summon enough goodness and courage to build, rather than tear down.
content: On the cliffs of Normandy, in a small holding area, the president of the United States was looking out at the English Channel. It was only six weeks ago, on the 80th anniversary of the D-Day landings, and President Biden had just finished his remarks at the American cemetery atop Omaha Beach. Guests had been congratulating him on the speech, but he didn’t want to talk about himself. The moment was not about him; it was about the men who had fought and died there. “Today feels so large,” he told me. “This may sound strange — and I don’t mean it to — but when I was out there, I felt the honor of it, the sanctity of it. To speak for the American people, to speak over those graves, it’s a profound thing.” He turned from the view over the beaches and gestured back toward the war dead. “You want to do right by them, by the country.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Here’s Where Kamala Harris Stands on Climate
description: She pursued polluters as attorney general in California and later staked out bold positions as a senator, including sponsorship of the Green New Deal.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris has for years made the environment a top concern, from prosecuting polluters as California’s attorney general to sponsoring the Green New Deal as a senator to casting the tiebreaking vote as vice president for the 2022 Inflation Reduction Act, the largest climate investment in United States history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Trump Donated to Kamala Harris’s Campaign When She Was California Attorney General
description: Years before either came close to the White House, Donald J. Trump gave $6,000 to her re-election campaign. His daughter Ivanka gave $2,000.
content: Long before former President Donald J. Trump and Vice President Kamala Harris were barreling toward a potential presidential showdown in November, Mr. Trump was one of her donors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: When Sports Games Feel Like Casinos, Players Rarely Win
description: Popular franchises like NBA 2K, FC and Madden entice players to keep spending. Critics say it’s ruining the games.
content: The price tag on the cover of most sports video games is only the beginning of what players are being asked to pay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: If Harris Is the Nominee, It Still Won’t Be Easy to Beat Trump
description: Biden’s age hasn’t been the only concern voters have been telling pollsters about recently.
content: Ever since Donald J. Trump won the presidency, Democrats have stuck to a winning electoral playbook: From congressional races to presidential ones, they’ve nominated well-liked, moderate candidates who could appeal to nearly any voter who disliked Mr. Trump and his allies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stuart A. Thompson
title: Far Right Spreads Baseless Claims About Biden’s Whereabouts
description: President Biden, who has been sidelined with Covid, is set to address the nation this week.
content: Many conspiracy theorists and far-right commentators are spreading doubts that President Biden is alive after he posted a letter on Sunday resigning from his presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: futile
description: This word has appeared in 184 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word futile has appeared in 184 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on June 15 in “Ukraine Peace Talks Held in Switzerland, Though Russia Isn’t Invited” by Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Anton Troianovski and Andrew E. Kramer:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: What’s the Matter With Madden?
description: After ESPN NFL 2K5 came out swinging in a battle of revered football video games, Madden scored an exclusive N.F.L. license. Twenty years later, its ratings are dismal.
content: A burst of innovation in the battle for National Football League fans transformed sports video games in an unexpected way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Robert L. Allen, Who Recounted a Naval Mutiny Trial, Dies at 82
description: He wrote of how 50 Black sailors were court-martialed for refusing to keep loading munitions onto cargo ships in 1944 after explosions had killed hundreds. They were exonerated this month.
content: Robert L. Allen, who definitively told the story of 50 Black sailors who were convicted of conspiracy to commit mutiny for refusing to continue to load munitions onto cargo ships after explosions had blown apart two ships at a California port during World War II, killing hundreds, died on July 10 at his home in Benicia, in Northern California. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Miller
title: Is This What Moving Toward Stability Feels Like?
description: The past month in American politics has been exhausting.
content: The past month has been overwhelming to live through — it can feel like a person’s mind is getting stretched and flattened by what’s happening in American politics and the world. One unbelievable event follows another, culminating in Joe Biden’s decision to withdraw from the presidential race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Orovic and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Gunman Kills at Least 6 at Nursing Home in Croatia
description: President Zoran Milanovic called for stricter gun control after an attack that shook Croatia, where mass killings are rare. A suspect was arrested nearby.
content: A gunman killed at least six people and wounded six others on Monday morning at a home for older and infirm people in Croatia, the country’s police chief told reporters Monday afternoon. He said that the attacker had used a handgun and that a suspect was quickly arrested at a restaurant nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austyn Gaffney
title: E.P.A. Announces $4.3 Billion in Funding for 25 Climate Projects
description: States, tribes, local governments and territories sent in proposals aimed at cutting greenhouse gas emissions.
content: The Environmental Protection Agency announced $4.3 billion in funding on Monday for 25 new projects proposed by states, tribes, local governments and territories to tackle climate change. The funding could reduce greenhouse gas emissions by as much as 971 million metric tons by 2050, or roughly the emissions of five million homes over 25 years, according to the agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Barbra Streisand and George Clooney Endorse Harris. Where Do Other Stars Stand?
description: Robert De Niro thanked President Biden, Spike Lee praised Vice President Kamala Harris and Aaron Sorkin backed her (not Mitt Romney) for the top of the ticket.
content: Barbra Streisand lent her support to Vice President Kamala Harris on Monday, becoming the latest in a series of high-profile stars and celebrities who have coalesced around her candidacy since President Biden endorsed her as his successor.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Spotlight Turns to Kamala Harris
description: Readers differ on whether she is the best Democratic candidate and praise President Biden for putting patriotism over pride.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: Joe Manchin Says He’s ‘Not Going to be a Candidate for President’
description: Manchin has flirted with running his own presidential bid as an independent.
content: Senator Joseph Manchin, independent of West Virginia, said on Monday that he would not launch his own presidential bid, a rapid shift in tone after a TV appearance earlier in the morning in which he appeared to be flirting with pursuit of the Democratic nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Chung and Yan Zhuang
title: Delta Cancels More Flights as It Struggles to Recover From Tech Outage
description: Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg singled out the airline on Sunday for ongoing disruptions and “unacceptable” customer service as it continued to cancel flights.
content: Three days after planes around the world were grounded by a technology outage, Delta Air Lines was struggling to get stranded passengers to their destinations on Monday and was the only carrier still canceling hundreds of flights as it raced to update its  systems.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorie Greenspan
title: How to Eat Like You’re in Paris for the Olympics
description: Dorie Greenspan, a beloved cookbook author and longtime Paris resident, knows that the French way of snacking is also the easiest.
content: For those living in Paris over the past few years, the opening ceremony for the Olympic Games may feel more like reaching the finish line than toeing it, exhausting for organizers and Parisians alike. Spiffing up the city for the Games has been like trying to complete all of Hercules’s labors at once, with so many miles of torn-up streets, capricious metro closings, bus detours to parts unknown and monuments swaddled Christo-style.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Tiny Tomatoes, Big Flavor
description: While we wait for big heirlooms to peak, dive into curry tomatoes and chickpeas, chile-crisp tofu and vegan pesto pasta salad.
content: We’re in the first stage of tomato season here in the Northeast, that part of summer when the rubicund beauties piled at the farmers’ market consistently tempt and deceive me. July tomatoes are pretty, but they’re just the vacant, mealy look-alikes of their flavorful, nectar-dripping August siblings. I must resist their siren song a bit longer before BLT season can truly begin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: Couple Who Attempted to Cross Atlantic Found Dead in Lifeboat
description: James Brett Clibbery and his wife, Sarah Justine Packwood, had left Nova Scotia on June 11, bound for the Azores. The authorities recovered remains believed to be theirs earlier this month.
content: The bodies of two sailors who planned to sail from Nova Scotia to the Azores using green energy were found washed ashore at a Canadian national park this month, four weeks after they were last seen, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Gene Gustines
title: A New Era for the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles Begins
description: As a comic book series to honor the Turtles’ 40th anniversary debuts, here’s a look back at their milestones.
content: The Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles are getting a new comic book series Wednesday, from IDW Publishing, to commemorate their 40th anniversary. Leonardo, Donatello, Raphael and Michelangelo have come a long way from their early comics days as turtles who, after being exposed to a mysterious green ooze, turned into sewer-dwelling heroes. They made the leap to animation, video games and merchandise. Here’s a look at some significant moments in Turtle history — and a glimpse at what lies ahead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar
title: How Media Outlets on the Left and Right Covered Biden’s Withdrawal
description: Progressive publications said President Biden’s decision to withdraw from the 2024 election was heroic. Conservative commentators suggested that if he is unable to campaign, he should step down from the presidency, too.
content: Political media across the spectrum devoted wall-to-wall news coverage and analysis of President Biden’s decision to withdraw from the 2024 presidential race. Depending on what outlet you watched, the decision was either exceptionally honorable or evidence of a “coup” by Democratic politicians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: ‘Two American Families’ Is a Knockout Documentary
description: This latest installment in a long-term Frontline series is an intimate look at two American families, who work hard but struggle to make ends meet.
content: The Frontline documentary “Two American Families: 1991-2024,” arriving on Tuesday, follows two Milwaukee families, one Black, one white, over the last 30-odd years. “Families” is intimate and dignified, unwavering but gentle. At a time when so much documentary television feels generic, disposable and even straightforwardly pointless, this is both a master work unto itself and a glaring reminder of what is largely absent in television narrative nonfiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Which Country Will Win the Paris Olympics? Don’t Just Count Medals.
description: Conventional ranking methods are flawed, but there’s a better way.
content: No nation officially wins the Olympics, but that doesn’t stop journalists and others from trying to keep score by counting gold, silver and bronze medals. Unfortunately, the two main approaches are equally flawed. The raw medal count overly favors populous nations, while ranking nations by medals per capita overly favors small nations that win one, two or a few medals, possibly by fluke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Katie Glueck
title: How Kamala Harris Will Try to Put Trump on Defense
description: Democrats are eager for her to deploy lines of attack that come more naturally than they did for President Biden, including on issues like abortion rights and the rule of law.
content: From the beginning of President Biden’s ill-fated re-election bid, Democrats struggled to frame the race as a choice between two radically different visions, rather than a referendum on Mr. Biden’s age and abilities.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer, Shane Goldmacher, Katie Glueck and Reid J. Epstein
title: Kamala Harris Rapidly Picks Up Democratic Support as 2024 Race Is Reborn
description: Endorsements cascaded in as the vice president took swift control of the Biden campaign in a transformed contest, though some key Democrats, including Barack Obama, did not immediately back her.
content: Powerful leaders of the Democratic establishment quickly embraced Vice President Kamala Harris on Sunday after President Biden’s shocking exit from the race, hoping that a seamless succession could end a month of damaging chaos and transform a contest widely believed to be tipping toward Republicans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Goddess of the Dawn
description: Laura Dershewitz’s first solo puzzle is a musical Monday grid.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Laura Dershewitz created her first crossword puzzle for The New York Times with Katherine Baicker in March. Now she is back with a solo puzzle just as clever and challenging as her collaborative debut. This crossword has it all: tricky fill, unconventional clues and a satisfying theme to bring it all together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Euan Ward
title: Israel Risks All-Out War With Hezbollah. A Truce in Gaza May Reduce That Threat.
description: After nine months of low-level conflict between Israel and Hezbollah, the risk of all-out war is higher than ever. A cease-fire in Gaza would provide an offramp for both sides, diplomats say.
content: For nine months, Israel and Hezbollah, an Iran-backed militia that dominates southern Lebanon, have fought a low-level conflict that has edged closer to an all-out war. Since October, both sides have fired thousands of missiles across the Israel-Lebanon border, wrecking towns, killing hundreds, displacing hundreds of thousands and leading both to threaten to invade the other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: A New Candidate Must Now Defend Biden’s Legacy Abroad
description: More than any election in decades, this one will be marked by starkly different approaches to an era of simultaneous confrontations, from China to Russia to the Middle East.
content: As President Biden greeted the leaders of his 31 allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization a week ago, he described in vivid terms how he thought history would treat his first term in office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei, Jenna Russell, Richard Fausset and Christina Morales
title: A Lot Has Changed for Women Since 2016. What Does That Mean for Kamala Harris?
description: Voters eager to elect the first female president pointed to anger over a loss of abortion rights, but also acknowledged a fear that sexism would remain difficult for Ms. Harris to overcome.
content: In the eight years since Hillary Clinton failed to win the American presidency, the work force for the first time grew to include more college-educated women than college-educated men. The #MeToo movement exposed sexual harassment and toppled powerful men. The Supreme Court overturned the federal right to abortion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: With Surprise Reversal, Biden Rewrites His Legacy and Makes a Play for History
description: Long concerned about his “epitaph,” the president reluctantly surrendered his bid for a second term, but Democrats argue that his willingness to give up power may yet enhance his role in posterity.
content: In his first memoir, President Biden reflected on what at the time was the most searing moment of his political career. He had withdrawn from his first presidential campaign in disgrace, driven out by charges of plagiarism. But he resolved not to let it be the end of his story. “A person’s epitaph,” he observed, “was written when his or her last battle was fought.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Paul Kuhn
title: ‘Politics Is About Tomorrow, Not Yesterday’
description: Joe Biden must have accepted that he is yesterday, and chose to let the party move on.
content: Lyndon Baines Johnson would fall asleep at night and imagine himself tied to the ground surrounded by thousands of voices, he once told Doris Kearns Goodwin. “They were all shouting at me and running toward me: ‘Coward! Traitor! Weakling!’ They kept coming closer. They began throwing stones.” Then he would awaken, “terribly shaken.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael C. Bender
title: Vance Criticizes Harris in First Solo Campaign Stops as Trump’s Running Mate
description: JD Vance stumped in Ohio and Virginia on Monday, in a race suddenly scrambled by President Biden’s announcement that he would not stand for re-election.
content: In JD Vance’s first solo day of campaigning as the Republican vice-presidential nominee, the Ohio senator questioned Vice President Kamala Harris’s appreciation for the United States and chastised her fellow Democrats for supporting President Biden “until he became political deadweight.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Netanyahu, Who Clashed With Biden, Prepares for a Delicate Farewell
description: The Israeli prime minister could expect a freer hand if Donald J. Trump returns to the presidency. But he must rely on President Biden for another six months.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is unlikely to immediately change his approach to the Gaza war following President Biden’s decision to stand aside, even if he may privately welcome the president’s departure from the race, analysts said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: A Kamala Harris Impersonator Is Ready for Her Moment
description: Allison Reese, a comedian, does TikTok’s favorite impression of the vice president. She’s about to have a busy week.
content: Moments after President Biden announced on Sunday that he was withdrawing from the 2024 presidential race, Allison Reese’s phone began flickering with text messages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold and Adam Goldman
title: The Questions the Secret Service Director Did Not Answer
description: On Monday, Kimberly A. Cheatle told a House committee that she could not reveal — or did not know — key details about the attempted assassination of President Trump. Here’s what was missing.
content: During a hearing before the House Committee on Oversight and Reform on Monday, several lawmakers, both Republicans and Democrats, expressed frustration with Secret Service Director Kimberly A. Cheatle over the number of questions that she would not — or could not — answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: A U.K. Deportation Plan Cost $900 Million. Only Four People Left.
description: Britain’s last Conservative government spent almost a billion dollars on its controversial plan to send asylum seekers to Rwanda, the newly appointed minister for immigration said Monday.
content: The previous British government spent far more than previously announced on a contentious plan to deport asylum seekers to Rwanda, it was announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikki Campo
title: These Nutrients Can Strengthen Aging Bones
description: Bone loss is a natural part of getting older, but prioritizing certain foods can help slow the process down.
content: As we age, our bodies break down more bone tissue than they build. This can increase the risk of osteoporosis, a condition defined by weak, brittle bones, which can make them more susceptible to breaks and fractures. And for older adults, the results can be devastating — broken or fractured bones may give way to lengthy hospital or nursing home stays, long-term disability or even death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Six Key Democratic Governors Endorse Kamala Harris
description: Gretchen Whitmer, JB Pritzker, Tim Walz, Wes Moore, Andy Beshear and Tony Evers all backed Ms. Harris, cutting off nearly all potential avenues to a challenge for the nomination.
content: Six key Democratic governors endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris on Monday, choking off what was perhaps the last prospect for a serious challenge to her claiming the party’s presidential nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Caitlin O'Keefe, Anna Foley and Elisa Gutierrez
title: Where Democrats Go Next
description: It took a donor revolt to get Biden to be the bridge to a new generation that he long talked about being. Now he’s all in for Harris.
content: When it finally happened, it felt both inevitable, and unfathomable.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Wordle Review No. 1,130, Tuesday, July 23, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal letters from today’s word, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Democrats Will Select Nominee by Aug. 7 in an Online Vote
description: The party, which has rapidly consolidated behind Vice President Kamala Harris to replace President Biden, did not set an exact date for the vote.
content: The Democratic Party will choose its presidential nominee in an online vote by Aug. 7, Jaime Harrison, the chair of the Democratic National Committee, said Monday on a call with reporters. A date for that vote has not yet been set.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Harris Raised $81 Million in First 24 Hours as Candidate
description: The funds will help rebuild a Democratic war chest that was at risk of being depleted in the weeks of uncertainty after President Biden’s poor debate, as big donors put a pause on fund-raising.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris raised $81 million in the first 24 hours since announcing her bid for president, her campaign said, a record-breaking showing as Democrats welcomed her candidacy with one of the greatest gushers of cash of all time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: In Silicon Valley, Where Trump Made Inroads, Democrats Are Now Invigorated
description: Elon Musk, Marc Andreessen and others have endorsed Donald J. Trump. But President Biden’s withdrawal has re-energized Democrats across the tech industry and may blunt that momentum.
content: In recent weeks, many Democrats in Silicon Valley had kept uncharacteristically quiet as prominent technology leaders — including Elon Musk and the investors Marc Andreessen and Ben Horowitz — endorsed Donald J. Trump for president.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: July 22, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 22, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hamed Aleaziz and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Homeland Security Secretary Announces Panel on Trump Assassination Attempt
description: Secretary Alejandro N. Mayorkas said the bipartisan group of experts would get to the bottom of decisions that allowed a gunman to wound the former president at a rally in Pennsylvania.
content: The homeland security secretary, Alejandro N. Mayorkas, on Sunday announced the members of a panel to conduct an independent review into security failures after a gunman was able to wound former President Donald J. Trump last weekend at a campaign rally in Butler, Pa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Assessing the Contentious Hearing on the Secret Service
description: We look at claims made by lawmakers and the director of the Secret Service during a hearing on the agency’s handling of the attempted assassination of former President Donald J. Trump.
content: Latest news: Kimberly Cheatle resigns as Secret Service director after Trump assassination attempt.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: He Loves Soccer and Portugal. So He Bought a Team.
description: Gifford Miller, a former City Council speaker who was Mayor Michael Bloomberg’s principal antagonist, has plunged into a new project since leaving politics.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll find out about a former City Council speaker who just bought a soccer team 3,400 miles from New York. We’ll also look at how a van could help people who are struggling with opioid addiction.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Colson Whitehead Looks Back at ‘The Underground Railroad’
description: The first in a series of conversations with authors appearing on our “Best Books of the 21st Century” list.
content: When we recently asked just over 500 writers and other literary experts and enthusiasts to offer their thoughts on the best works of the 21st century so far, we thought it would also be fun to ask some of the writers represented to reflect on their books and careers. In the first of those interviews, Colson Whitehead remembers what it was like to write and publish “The Underground Railroad”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Hunter Biden Drops Lawsuit Against Fox News Over Nude Photos
description: A judge also threw out a separate lawsuit against the network brought by a specialist in Russian disinformation.
content: Hunter Biden, President Biden’s son, withdrew a lawsuit against Fox News on Sunday that had accused the network of violating a revenge porn law by sharing explicit photos and videos of him without his permission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Pelosi Endorses Harris, Ending Speculation She Would Push for Open Primary
description: Before President Biden dropped out, the former House speaker had told her some colleagues privately that if he were to do so, she would favor a competitive primary.
content: Representative Nancy Pelosi, the former speaker who played a critical role in making the case privately to President Biden that he should withdraw from the presidential race, on Monday formally endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris to replace him as the party’s nominee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Theodore Schleifer
title: Female Donors Mobilize for Harris, Moving to Stamp Out Opposition
description: Vice President Kamala Harris has an orbit of Bay Area billionaires and loyalists, all women, who can power her bid for the Democratic nomination. But some big donors are still seeking other options.
content: For decades, Kamala Harris has been bolstered by a tight-knit group of female donors who rose up with her in Democratic politics. And for weeks, even when she was still insisting that President Biden would be the party’s nominee, these allies began to make moves to make sure her historic campaign would not be built on the fly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: One Night of TV Canceled a President
description: President Biden’s decision to bow out after a disastrous debate confirms that in a TikTok era, TV is still the biggest political arena.
content: As soon as TV sets landed in American living rooms, media critics worried that television would dominate politics, and the medium wasted no time proving them right. Richard M. Nixon lost in 1960 to the glamorous John F. Kennedy after a shaky, sweaty debate that played better for him on the radio. After Ronald Reagan zingered his way to a second term in 1984, Neil Postman wrote that in the TV era, “debates were conceived as boxing matches.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Two Killed in Plane Crash Near Wisconsin Air Show
description: Emergency responders found a plane engulfed in flames in a farm field near the Experimental Aircraft Association AirVenture showcase in Oshkosh.
content: Two people were killed on Monday in a plane crash in Wisconsin outside the grounds of one of the biggest air shows in the United States, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Kamala Harris Takes Control
description: President Biden has dropped out of the race. We answer four questions about what happens next.
content: With President Biden having dropped out of the race, I’m devoting today’s newsletter to four big questions about what happens next. My colleagues and I will also give you the latest news about the campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: He Replaced the King of Sexy. Now He’s Leaving.
description: After spending 25 years as Tom Ford’s right-hand man — at Gucci and then at his namesake label — Peter Hawkings survived less than a year as his successor.
content: “At the end of the day, desire is what makes the world go around, and Tom Ford is synonymous with desire,” the designer Peter Hawkings told Vogue in 2023. Newly anointed as the creative director of the Tom Ford brand at the time — the only person to hold the position besides its founder — Mr. Hawkings was charged with bringing Ford-style sexy back, though in his own fashion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: She Found Bounties in Small Towns, Local Talk and Everyday Life
description: The simple pleasures keep coming in this keenly observed collection by the Argentinian writer Hebe Uhart.
content: Rebecca West, in an elegy for D.H. Lawrence, recalled that when he arrived in a new city, he would race from the rail station to his hotel room and “immediately sit down and hammer out articles about the place, vehemently and exhaustively describing the temperament of the people.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Schumer and Jeffries Stop Short of Endorsing Harris, as Support Piles Up
description: Representative Nancy Pelosi, the influential former speaker, announced her support for the vice president, but the two top Democrats in Congress stayed neutral, saying she was “off to a great start.”
content: The two top Democrats in Congress stopped short on Monday of endorsing Vice President Kamala Harris for president, even as dozens of lawmakers rapidly lined up behind her. However, the leaders praised her for amassing support from all corners of the party as she seeks to claim the nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: Memes, Texts and Other Jarring Ways Some Americans Heard the Biden News
description: When the president announced he was suspending his re-election bid, the news spread via some unexpected sources.
content: Jordan Feldman found out that President Biden was ending his campaign for a second term from Liza Minnelli.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Salam
title: ‘Homicide: Life on the Street’ Will Finally Be Available to Stream
description: The celebrated 1990s police procedural is coming to Peacock in August.
content: The critically acclaimed 1990s police procedural “Homicide: Life on the Street” will soon be available to stream in its entirety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: U.S. Olympic Committee Sues Logan Paul’s Drink Company
description: The suit accuses Prime Hydration of using trademarked terms including “Olympic” and “Team USA” to promote a sports drink that features Kevin Durant.
content: The U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee says Coca-Cola has the exclusive right to use Olympic trademarks, including the words “Olympic” and “Team USA,” on beverages in the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: For Some Old Musicals, Not Just Revival but Reappropriation
description: How a Black lieutenant, a gay kiss and a catless ballroom are helping reclaim Broadway classics.
content: Ten years ago, I cringed through an Encores! performance of one of the most odious musicals I’d ever seen. That’s not to throw shade on Encores!, the concert series that dredges up both diamonds and dirt from the musical theater dustbin. But “Irma La Douce,” a 1960 Broadway hit about jolly prostitutes and the men who keep them, was perhaps a dredge too far. Did I mention that it involved penguins?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Chair of Police Oversight Board Resigns After Mayor Adams Pushes Her Out
description: Arva Rice, who led the Civilian Complaint Review Board, had criticized the Police Department and sought more power and funding for the independent agency.
content: The interim head of an independent civilian police oversight board in New York, who had criticized the Police Department and had sought more investigative power and funding for the agency, resigned on Monday after being forced out by Mayor Eric Adams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Eminem Ends Taylor Swift’s Chart Run With His 11th No. 1 Album
description: The rapper’s “The Death of Slim Shady (Coup de Grâce)” replaced the pop superstar’s “The Tortured Poets Department” after 12 weeks of dominance at the top.
content: Eventually someone had to come along and bump Taylor Swift from No. 1 on the Billboard album chart — and it was Eminem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Women Voters: Is the Country Ready for a Female President? Tell Us.
description: Let us know how you feel about a woman running for president in 2024.
content: President Biden announced on Sunday that he was dropping out of the presidential race and endorsed Vice President Kamala Harris to replace him as the Democratic nominee. If elected, Ms. Harris, 59, would be the nation’s first woman president. Eight years after Hillary Clinton lost to former President Donald J. Trump, is the country ready?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Monday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: President Biden abandoned his bid for re-election yesterday, succumbing to intense pressure from the Democratic Party in a dramatic attempt to stop Donald Trump from returning to the White House. No sitting U.S. president has dropped out of a race so late in an election cycle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Trump’s Cynical Attempt to Pit Recent Immigrants Against Black Americans
description: No, Black workers aren’t being “decimated” by new immigrants.
content: Obviously, the big political news of the past couple of days has come from the Democratic side. But before last week’s Republican National Convention fades from view, let me focus instead on a development on the G.O.P. side that may, given everything else that has been happening, have flown under the radar: MAGA rhetoric on immigration, which was already ugly, has become even uglier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean Catangui and Jason M. Bailey
title: Readers Share Their Favorite Sports Video Games (Boomshakalaka!)
description: NHL ’94 and MVP Baseball 2005 live on decades later. So do the arcade-style games NBA Jam and Mario Tennis.
content: When we asked readers to share their memories of their favorite sports video games, the responses included 8-bit classics from the 1990s and cooperative brawls played with gesture-controlled joysticks some two decades later. Many of these were played with close friends or family, huddled around the TV.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeré Longman and Oleksandr Chubko
title: The Decathlete Who Picked Up a Gun
description: About 500 top-level Ukrainian athletes and coaches have died in the war. Volodymyr Androshchuk promised his loved ones he would make it back.
content: On a rest day from the war in Ukraine, Volodymyr Androshchuk went out for sushi. In a cheap car, recently purchased, he drove his squad leader to a supermarket a short distance from the eastern front. They ate at a safe house and shared a small bottle of Cognac.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Illinois State Police Release Footage of Deputy Fatally Shooting Woman
description: The woman, Sonya Massey, 36, called 911 on July 6 because she believed there was an intruder in her home. She was fatally shot by a sheriff’s deputy who has been fired and is charged with murder.
content: In a case that has drawn the attention of President Biden, the Illinois State Police on Monday released disturbing body camera footage that showed a sheriff’s deputy fatally shooting a woman in the head in an exchange over a pot of water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Biden Vows to Campaign Hard for Harris, Saying, ‘I’m Not Going Anywhere’
description: The president called into a meeting with Vice President Kamala Harris at what was once their joint campaign headquarters, the first time he has been heard since isolating with Covid last week.
content: President Biden declared on Monday that he was “not going anywhere” and would be “fully, fully engaged,” as he vowed to campaign hard to elect Vice President Kamala Harris and to use his final six months in office to keep pressing for his priorities at home and abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Ukraine Strikes Preliminary $20 Billion Debt Restructuring Deal
description: The deal with private bondholders will help preserve Kyiv’s limited state budget, which is crucial to fund its military. An agreement to suspend debt payments was to expire on Aug. 1.
content: Ukraine said Monday that it had struck a preliminary deal with a group of international private creditors to restructure more than $20 billion of the debt it owes them, a step that would save the war-torn country billions and preserve funds to support its battered armed forces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: This Was Never Going to Be Boring
description: “I know it’s been a roller coaster,” Vice President Kamala Harris told her campaign staff on Monday.
content: Remember a month ago?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney and Jennifer Medina
title: Kamala Harris Turns to Selecting a Possible Vice President
description: The first big decision for Ms. Harris: Who will be her running mate if she is nominated by the Democratic Party to run for president in August.
content: After weeks of speculation, Vice President Kamala Harris, endorsed by President Biden to succeed him as the Democratic presidential candidate this fall, will have a bench of new-generation party leaders to turn to when she moves toward the first critical decision of her candidacy: picking a running mate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: A Deadly Robbery Reveals a Pattern of Targeting Latinos in Alabama’s Capital
description: Latinos in Montgomery, Ala., said they had been sounding the alarm for months, describing the killings at a grocery store as the culmination of unchecked violence.
content: On the afternoon of June 4, Billy Daniel López García was making plans for the future. He took his girlfriend to a jewelry store and surprised her with a silver promise ring. He vowed to propose after her 20th birthday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Claire Fahy
title: Parents of Teen Driver Who Killed Girl in High-Speed Crash Are Sentenced
description: The boy, then 16, survived and has been charged in the death of his 14-year-old passenger. His parents were sentenced to probation and ordered to take parenting classes.
content: A New York couple who bought their 16-year-old son a BMW were sentenced on Monday to three years of probation and 26 weeks of parenting classes after the teenager drove the car at speeds of more than 100 miles an hour, slammed into a truck and killed his passenger, a 14-year-old girl.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: Silicon Valley Investors’ Plans for a New City Put on Hold
description: The East Solano Plan, a proposal for a walkable urban community in a rural corner of the San Francisco Bay Area, stoked tension, fear and mistrust among some neighbors.
content: Silicon Valley’s plans for a start-up city are on hold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Darren Walker, Who Reoriented the Ford Foundation, Will Step Down
description: Mr. Walker, who oversaw $7 billion in grants, plans to leave at the end of 2025 after what will have been 12 years.
content: Darren Walker, the president of the Ford Foundation, one of the nation’s largest and most influential philanthropies, recently recalled the day his assistant excitedly told him that President Barack Obama wanted to meet him. He gently corrected her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Kimmelman
title: Hosting the Olympics Costs Billions. What Does a City Get Back?
description: The Games are supposed to be a fast track to urban renewal. The reality is often the opposite.
content: It was a sunny morning in mid-June and the athletes’ village for the Summer Olympics, in Seine-Saint-Denis, just outside Paris, was still nominally under construction. Workers sweated in hard hats and yellow vests, watching over the empty site. Built in the midst of various housing developments, the village sprawls across 128 riverine acres. Several dozen new, mostly beige, timber-frame apartment blocks, pleasant but banal, spill down to a tree-lined promenade along the Seine. Luc Besson’s former film studio complex, in a converted power plant, has been partly turned into the athletes’ mess hall. Next door, another power plant, gut renovated and whitewashed, which now houses a gym, will become office space for 2,500 civil servants in France’s Ministry of the Interior after the Games are done.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jess Bidgood
title: Biden Is Out, and Democrats Have a Whole New Set of Questions
description: An earthshaking political moment finally arrived, and the transformation of the campaign starts now.
content: It’s over.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Bernstein
title: A Culture War on Wheels
description: Elon Musk’s Cybertruck is inspiring a lot of strong feelings.
content: If a car can embody the age that created it, the Tesla Cybertruck is, fittingly, a culture war on wheels.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Farber
title: Duke Fakir, Last Surviving Member of the Four Tops, Dies at 88
description: He sang tenor on hits like “Standing in the Shadows of Love,” “Reach Out, I’ll Be There” and “I Can’t Help Myself (Sugar Pie Honey Bunch).”
content: Abdul Fakir, who was known as Duke, the last remaining original member of the Four Tops, one of Motown’s best-selling and most beloved groups, died on Monday at his home in Detroit. He was 88.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Why Are There Neo-Nazis on the Streets of Nashville?
description: The shameless presence of white supremacists here tells us something about the similarity between the politics of the past and our political moment.
content: I wish I could say I was shocked when neo-Nazis started parading around downtown Nashville last week, wearing shirts emblazoned with swastikas and the words “Pro-white.” I wish I could say I was shocked when they asked passers-by, “Are you a Jew?,” or when they terrified a child, or when they unfurled a hate-filled banner for interstate drivers to see, or when they threatened local businesses with violence. Even on Tuesday night, when they disrupted a meeting of the Metro Council, spouting “antisemitic, homophobic and racist diatribes,” according to the Nashville Scene’s Eli Motycka, I couldn’t say I was surprised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Paul Watson, Anti-Whaling Activist, Is Detained in Greenland
description: Mr. Watson, the founder of the conservation group Sea Shepherd, was arrested when his boat docked in Nuuk. He could face extradition to Japan.
content: Paul Watson, a prominent anti-whaling activist, was arrested in Greenland on Sunday and may be extradited to Japan, where he is being sought on an international arrest warrant, Mr. Watson’s organization said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Biden Shepherded Europe on Ukraine and NATO. What Happens Now?
description: President Biden’s stance on Ukraine was shaped by a deep commitment to America’s trans-Atlantic alliance. Some Europeans fear he may be among the last of his kind.
content: European leaders have been relying on President Biden to guide them through some of the continent’s darkest days in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: How Kamala Harris Rose as a California Moderate
description: Ms. Harris, who was born in the state, amassed power through her work as a prosecutor.
content: She has been slammed by the right-wing news media as a far-left politician, a radical creature of affirmative action whom Democrats had positioned to become “the country’s first D.E.I. president.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Ready to Realize a New Dream
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 22, 2024.
content: “Life is weird, anyways. Who cares if it gets a little weirder?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Peter Baker, Jessica Cheung, Shannon M. Lin, Sydney Harper, Olivia Natt, Carlos Prieto, Lynsea Garrison, Devon Taylor, Dan Powell, Will Reid and Chris Wood
title: Joe Biden Drops Out
description: The president’s decision not to seek re-election upended the race and set the stage for a raucous and unpredictable campaign.
content: President Biden has dropped out of the 2024 presidential race and endorsed his vice president, Kamala Harris, as his replacement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: ‘Barbie’ Was Supposed to Change Hollywood for Women. Why Didn’t It?
description: The film was a global phenomenon and seemed to herald a new era of embracing stories by, about and for women.
content: When “Barbie” was released in 2023, it quickly became a phenomenon. It was the top box office film of the year, earning $1.4 billion worldwide, and it became Warner Bros.’s highest-grossing film ever, outpacing both “Dark Knight” movies, “Wonder Woman” and every chapter in the “Harry Potter” franchise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Impulsive and Hyperactive? It Doesn’t Mean You Have A.D.H.D.
description: Many other conditions have similar symptoms, experts say, so avoid the pull of self-diagnosis.
content: The 6-year-old boy sitting across from Douglas Tynan, a child and adolescent clinical psychologist based in Delaware, clearly did not have attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Dr. Tynan was sure of that. But the boy’s first-grade teacher disagreed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tracy Mumford, Lisa Lerer, Ian Stewart and Jessica Metzger
title: Top Democrats Swing Behind Harris after Biden Exits Race
description: Plus, Secret Service chief to face a House hearing.
content: On Today’s Episode:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, David A. Fahrenthold, Hamed Aleaziz and Campbell Robertson
title: Seeking Answers, Lawmakers From Both Parties Ask Secret Service Chief to Quit
description: In a hearing on Capitol Hill, Director Kimberly A. Cheatle declined to answer questions about the lapses in protection that allowed a gunman to fire at former President Donald Trump in Butler, Pa.
content: The Secret Service director, Kimberly A. Cheatle, faced bipartisan calls for her resignation on Monday, after a disastrous hourslong congressional hearing in which she declined to answer basic questions about the attempted assassination of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: A Senator Will Preside at Netanyahu’s Speech to Congress After Harris Declines
description: An aide to Vice President Kamala Harris said she had a scheduling conflict but would meet with the Israeli prime minister this week.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris has declined to preside on Wednesday when Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is scheduled to address a joint meeting of Congress, staying away from a gathering that is likely to highlight the deep divisions among Democrats about his conduct of the war with Hamas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: Olympians Are Getting Loads and Loads of Gear
description: Athletes are unboxing sponsored merchandise and sharing try-on hauls on TikTok, featuring brands like Nike and Lululemon.
content: In three separate TikTok posts, Evy Leibfarth, a canoeist competing in the 2024 Paris Olympics for Team U.S.A., unboxed several duffel bags and suitcases she had received from brand sponsors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By River Akira Davis
title: SoftBank’s Chief Pitches a New Path for Self-Driving Cars
description: Masayoshi Son, the billionaire founder of SoftBank, is trying to rally automakers around the world to join forces on autonomous-driving technologies.
content: Masayoshi Son has long prided himself on his ability to detect big shifts in technology early on. During his four decades leading SoftBank, a free-spending Japanese investment group, the billionaire has made some spectacularly successful investments. And some epic flops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Evan Rail
title: From Berlin to Paris on the Night Train: A Retro-Romantic Journey
description: Comfort was at times questionable and the food so-so, but for everyone on board, the trip was an experience unto itself.
content: Step 1: Board the train. Step 2: Climb into bed. Step 3: Wake up at your destination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Esta TerBlanche, ‘All My Children’ Star, Dies at 51
description: Ms. TerBlanche played Gillian Andrassy, a Hungarian princess whose story line was beloved by fans.
content: Esta TerBlanche, a South African actress best known for her role on “All My Children,” died on Thursday in Los Angeles. She was 51.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: Judge Who Threatened to Shoot Black Teens Should Be Removed, Panel Says
description: Justice Erin P. Gall of upstate New York engaged in a “racially offensive, profane” diatribe after people crashed a large party she was attending, a disciplinary body found.
content: A New York disciplinary panel said on Monday that a state judge should be removed from office for engaging in a “racially offensive, profane” diatribe during which she invoked her judicial position, threatened to shoot Black teenagers and expressed a bias in favor of the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: How These 10 Democrats Would Fare Against Trump, Rated by Our Columnists and Writers
description: Many party leaders are coalescing behind Kamala Harris, but some veteran Democrats — and many voters — are still grappling with who would fare best against Trump.
content: Many party leaders are coalescing behind Kamala Harris, but some veteran Democrats — and many voters — are still grappling with who would fare best against Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lazaro Gamio, John Keefe, June Kim, Alyce McFadden, Andrew Park and Karen Yourish
title: Many Elected Democrats Quickly Endorsed Kamala Harris. See Who Did.
description: Every Democratic governor and a majority of Democrats in Congress have come out in support of Ms. Harris’s candidacy.
content: Every Democratic governor and a majority of Democrats in Congress have come out in support of Ms. Harris’s candidacy.

title: How Well Do You Know Literary Brooklyn?
description: This bustling borough of New York City has been the setting for many novels — including the books in this short quiz.
content: This bustling borough of New York City has been the setting for many novels — including the books in this short quiz.

title: Who Might Kamala Harris Pick as Her Running Mate?
description: The first big decision for Ms. Harris: Who will be her running mate if she is nominated by the Democratic Party to run for president in August.
content: The first big decision for Ms. Harris: Who will be her running mate if she is nominated by the Democratic Party to run for president in August.

author: By The New York Times
title: Harris Commends Biden’s Record at N.C.A.A. White House Event
description: A day after being endorsed by President Biden, Vice President Kamala Harris spoke at an event celebrating N.C.A.A. champions where she praised Biden and spoke fondly about her friendship with Beau Biden.
content: A day after being endorsed by President Biden, Vice President Kamala Harris spoke at an event celebrating N.C.A.A. champions where she praised Biden and spoke fondly about her friendship with Beau Biden.

author: By Battle Mountain Complex Via Storyful
title: Wildfires Burn More Than 620,000 Acres in Oregon and Washington
description: There were 22 fires burning in Oregon and six in Washington on Sunday, according to the Northwest Interagency Coordination Center.
content: There were 22 fires burning in Oregon and six in Washington on Sunday, according to the Northwest Interagency Coordination Center.

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: Secret Service Director Faces Bipartisan Calls to Resign
description: The Secret Service director, Kimberly A. Cheatle, repeatedly refused to answer specific questions in a House oversight committee hearing on security failures that led to an assassination attempt on former President Donald J. Trump.
content: The Secret Service director, Kimberly A. Cheatle, repeatedly refused to answer specific questions in a House oversight committee hearing on security failures that led to an assassination attempt on former President Donald J. Trump.

author: By Peter Baker, Claire Hogan, Rebecca Suner, Alexandra Ostasiewicz and James Surdam
title: Joe Biden Dropped Out. What’s Next?
description: President Biden on Sunday abruptly abandoned his campaign for a second term under intense pressure from fellow Democrats and threw his support to Vice President Kamala Harris to lead their party in a dramatic last-minute bid to stop former President Donald J. Trump from returning to the White House. Peter Baker, the chief White House correspondent for The New York Times, explains what happened as Mr. Biden decided to withdraw, and what could happen next.
content: President Biden on Sunday abruptly abandoned his campaign for a second term under intense pressure from fellow Democrats and threw his support to Vice President Kamala Harris to lead their party in a dramatic last-minute bid to stop former President Donald J. Trump from returning to the White House. Peter Baker, the chief White House correspondent for The New York Times, explains what happened as Mr. Biden decided to withdraw, and what could happen next.
source.name: The New York Times
